title: Before 1 January 2023, will North Korea launch an ICBM with an estimated range of at least 10,000 km?
preds:
"SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — South Korea on Tuesday dismissed North Korea’s claim to have launched a newly developed intercontinental ballistic missile last week, accusing the country of firing a less-powerful existing weapon and fabricating data following an earlier failed launch. North Korea said it launched a Hwasong-17 missile, its longest-range developmental ICBM, last Thursday in its biggest weapons test in years. Its state media called the launch “a historical event” and released a stylized Hollywood-style video showing leader Kim Jong Un, in sunglasses and leather jacket, supervising the launch. But South Korea’s Defense Ministry said Tuesday it has determined that what North Korea fired wasn’t a Hwasong-17 but a Hwasong-15, another ICBM that it successfully tested in 2017. Both missiles are potentially capable of reaching the U.S. mainland. But analysts say the Hwasong-17 has a longer potential range and its huge size suggests that it’s designed to carry multiple nuclear warheads to defeat missile defense systems. Believed to be about 25 meters (82 feet) long, the Hwasong-17 is, by some estimates, the world’s biggest road-mobile ballistic missile system. The Defense Ministry said it told a parliamentary committee that details of Thursday’s launch -- such as the missile’s speed, combustion and stage separation -- were similar to those of the Hwasong-15, not the Hwasong-17. The ministry report to the committee also suggested that the North Korean video wasn’t shot on the actual launch date, citing an analysis of Kim’s shadow and weather conditions seen in the video."
https://apnews.com/article/business-seoul-south-korea-north-korea-47a7e85c51102bc023db53c6c093186d "[...] 
Range
    8,500 – 13,000 km 
Status
    Operational
In service
    2017"
https://missilethreat.csis.org/missile/hwasong-15-kn-22/

Still waiting on CSIS to update their records and resolve the question. They haven't updated Hwasong 15 since July 2021:  https://missilethreat.csis.org/missile/hwasong-15-kn-22/ The article they posted about the launch the other day still doesn't resolve the issue ( https://missilethreat.csis.org/north-korea-tests-icbm-2/ ) although multiple other specialist sources do estimate that it's exceeded the 10,000km potential range specified by the question. Really not sure why CSIS are dragging their feet at this point.

CSIS, let's get this one closed out! "The South Korean and Japanese militaries had announced similar flight details, which analysts say suggested that the missile could reach targets 15,000 kilometers (9,320 miles) away when fired on normal trajectory with a warhead weighing less than a ton." https://www.militarytimes.com/flashpoints/2022/03/24/north-korea-confirms-test-firing-of-biggest-icbm/?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=EBB%2003.25.2022&utm_term=Editorial%20-%20Early%20Bird%20Brief
Appears to be resolved like @belikewater states.

Repeating my forecast. North Korea launched an ICBM today, probably either a Hwasong-15 or Hwasong-17, from reports I've seen. According to the text of the question, "the estimated range of a launched ICBM will be determined using data and reporting provided by the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS)." This means that the question will resolve when CSIS publishes a news item that states which ICBM was launched, which will probably be tomorrow, although it could take a little longer than that. We need CSIS to determine which ICBM was launched, because that will determine the estimated range. In any case, Hwasong-15 and Hwasong-17 both have 10,000 km+ ranges, so this question is effectively done. Later edit: CSIS has posted an article that resolves the question to yes: https://missilethreat.csis.org/north-korea-tests-icbm-2/

Leaving 1% “wiggle room” in case preliminary analysis doesn’t stick and/or if evidence deemed insufficient by GJO. Otherwise it seems that this Question has triggered. “ South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff said on Thursday it detected the launch of an “unidentified projectile” from North Korea. It said the launch was assumed to be a long-range missile, possibly an ICBM fired on a “lofted” trajectory. It added in a statement that “our military jointly fired missiles from ground, sea, air,” from 16:25 (7:25 GMT) in response to North Korea’s action.” https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2022/3/24/north-korea-launches-suspected-icbm-in-first-such-test-since-2017

They've just launched one with a trajectory of around 6,000 km. : https://edition.cnn.com/2022/03/24/asia/north-korea-missile-test-intl-hnk/index.html "The data suggested that the missile was more powerful than the Hwasong-15":  https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/03/24/world/north-korea-icbm-launch/north-korea-icbm-launch "It's Hwasong-15 missile is believed to have a range of 13,000km, putting all of the continental US in its sights.":  https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-41174689 Therefore the estimated range exceeds <10,000km

Japan says North Korea had tested an ICBM which crashed into waters west of Japan. 
The NYT reported the missile reached an altitude of 3,728 miles, as per Japanese officials.  "The data suggested that the missile launched on Thursday (March 24, 2022)  was more powerful than the Hwasong-15," the last ICBM North Korea tested in 2017
+10 %, due to recent events and SK intel.

South Korean intel reacting to the same pattern a couple of days ago:
http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20220314000706 https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/south-korea-sees-imminent-prospect-north-icbm-test-newspaper-2022-03-14/ Last night the North Koreans actually fired one but it blew up on the launchpad in what seems to have been a catastrophic failure (an engineering term indicating that the missile's integrity failed) - this is humiliating for them and they will want to launch an effective one to save face: https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-60760766 They have nonetheless proven the intent & will behind the suggestive preparatory pattern from the weeks beforehand.    With the intent/will element being proved, now the question turns on on their actual capacity to launch one with an estimated effective range of 10,000km. My money is on yes.
lots of chatter, i wonder how often SK and the US are wrong about NK's "planned" missile launches.

If previous launch not counted, more to come: https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/south-korea-sees-imminent-prospect-north-icbm-test-newspaper-2022-03-14/?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=EBB%2003.14.2022&utm_term=Editorial%20-%20Early%20Bird%20Brief

I'm already at 100%, but I thought I'd share that it looks like NK is about to launch another ICBM, in addition to the 2 launched recently.
https://twitter.com/Angry_Staffer/status/1503051965944766471
https://twitter.com/Rover829/status/1503031849697828869

Are we using range? If so I am not sure this resolves the question, but they did say ICBM. https://www.defense.gov/News/Releases/Release/Article/2963053/statement-by-pentagon-press-secretary-john-kirby-on-recent-dprk-missile-tests/source/statement-by-pentagon-press-secretary-john-kirby-on-recent-dprk-missile-tests/
Up 20% on US announcement. The one I saw mentioned SLV.
New ICBM launch didn’t test range, but I figure this ups the chance that more ICBMs will be tested soon, perhaps testing range the next time.

http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20220309000027 https://www.armscontrol.org/act/2022-03/news/experts-discover-north-korean-icbm-base https://thediplomat.com/2022/03/north-korea-launches-ballistic-missile-for-reconnaissance-satellite-test/ These would together seem to constitute a suggestive pattern of preparatory behaviour
Up 5% to be above the consensus. Still thinking any test will be a SLV.

Increasing again based on historical patterns of escalation. Kim will likely keep ratcheting things up until they acquire the attention of the Biden administration and some much-needed economic relief. The U.S., however, is now focused on Ukraine. Another key factor will be who is elected in South Korea as the new President and their respective views on the DPRK.

I think if this Ukraine tension embroils to a more global conflict then YES. If not, if they had one, they'd already have launched one. I think they mostly talk loudly bc they don't want to be invaded. I do think it's possible however that if they have such technology as has been claimed that it could be via submarine somewhere or just a poker hand bluff.

Saw an article that there seems to be a previously undetected ICBM facility(ies) near the China–North Korea border. This may be a precursor to a future launch that would push this question to resolve YES. T-minus 10 months and counting.
It hurts The Pyongyang Kid's feelings if people aren't paying enough attention to him.  He'll see if this works.

Decrease for half a month (2.8%/ month, so 1.4% for half a month). Additionally, I feel like that with the world all wired up on Ukraine no one would even care if North Korea would launch an ICBM at this point. Therefore, I will double my decrease (to 2.8% / half month) and round it off to 3%. Thus, 26-3 = 23% probability.

If my understanding of the data given for the Hwasong-14 ICBM is right, the missile has already a high end of potential range of 9 700km (some sources say 10 400km : https://allthingsnuclear.org/dwright/new-north-korean-icbm/)  using the Earth rotation, and was tested in 2017 (https://www.38north.org/2017/07/jschilling071017/). The sources given here talk about "booster-glider" new types, but these can according to these same sources already be considered as ICBMs.
Given the closeness of the 2017 figures to the end state of the question, and assuming "launch" means "initiated takeoff, with end data implying capacity", and that NK has been testing missiles several times per year every year since 2019, I think this is extremely likely.
Up 10% to be ahead of the consensus. A SLV would be the least costly, but still impactful.
Emboldened by Russian actions and the West’s tepid response has me moving

After successfully shown ICBM capability North-Korea has moved to develope short range hypersonic missiles. Because NK's tech development capabilities are limited it is very unlikely that it will re-test ICBM
Keeping this higher than the crowd, because of the possibility of regime misbehavior while the rest of the world is focused on Russia/Ukraine turmoil.
With the way the World in going, why not?
The NK phallic obsession with length and power will drive the programme forward until the regime falls or China imposes punitive measures to stop it.
Up 5% to be ahead of the consensus. Still "expect" a SLV.

Started on January 16th, I will decrease linearly from 28% to 0% till the 1st of January 2023: 2.8% / month decrease. So, this time from 28% to 26%.  Found no significant news that influenced my percentage so far.

(no change) In "general" nuclear powers with missiles test the latter from some "test" facility. This reduces the chances of errors (possible adversaries doing something that all might regret) although NOTAMs, BOAAs, etc. also are normally provided. I may not be in the majority, but I believe (for the DPRK) that KJU actually acts very rationally related to both missiles and nukes. Another reason to not launch a test from a new and "improved" silo thingy is that there might be a few eyes and ears looking for some interesting data about the operations and site. YMMV

North Korea Builds ICBM Base Near China as Fears of New Test Loom
The location is meant to protect its most powerful weapons from pre-emptive strikes, allowing the military to expand an already rapidly growing arsenal.
https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/08/world/asia/north-korea-icbm-china.html

- Under Kim Jong-Un's rule (since 2011) there have been 3 ICBM (10k) launches, all in 2017. That's an average of around 0.27 ICBM launches per year. However, 2017 is the first time they were willing/able to do it, so the 0.27 number is not very useful.
- The only ICBM capable missiles that they own are the Hwasong-13,14, and 15.
- They have launched 9 missiles so far this year, a much higher rate than all previous years. One of those was a Hwasong-12, the first one fired since 2017.
- In a Workers' Party meeting on Jan. 19, North Korea hinted that it was contemplating scrapping the regime's self-imposed moratorium on nuclear and longer range missile testing that has been in place since the end of 2017.
- A Washington think tank said on Monday it has identified a military base close to North Korea's border with China that is likely intended for stationing ICBMs.
- Launching an ICBM would definitely lead to even more sanctions. 
- There are 2 big 'celebratory events' this year that could coincide with launches, as has been the case historically. More activity and more rhetoric but, To move sanction talks forward, I think Kim can/will make a lot of noise without launching an ICBM. All that will achieve is even more sanctions.
ICBM capabilities discovered at NK base: https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/08/world/asia/north-korea-icbm-china.html

Keeping my forecast based on the number of recent DPRK missile tests.  Although short and medium-range tests, these tests and their frequency could mean the knowledge/results are being used to inform their scientific community about how to improve long-range capabilities.  In addition, note the NYT article discussing a new ICBM base being build near the Chinese boarder with the DPRK.  I speculate long-range ICBM tests are the intent of the base and therefore do not relax my expectations a test will happen before 1 Jan 2023, depending on how quickly the base is built.

North Korea’s Latest Missile Test Appears to Be Its Boldest in Years
Flight data indicates that the launch on Sunday was the North’s most powerful since 2017. South Korean analysts expect further escalations from Kim Jong-un.
https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/29/world/asia/north-korea-missile-test.html North Korea's Hwasong-14 first tested in July 2017:  "Calculations of the range of the Hwasong-14 carrying such a payload vary from 6,000 km (3,700 mi), enough to reach Anchorage, to as much as 8,000 km (5,000 mi), enough to reach Honolulu, Hawaii and Seattle, Washington; the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists claimed the payload would need to be lighter at 300 kg (660 lb) to be able to reach Seattle. The July 2017 tests were conducted with a 200 kg (440 lb) reentry vehicle, giving the missile its maximum range of 10,400 km (6,500 mi), enough to reach New York City but not Washington D.C., although such a payload is much lighter than North Korea is believed to be capable of weaponizing."  It's possible that if geopolitical situation with Russia worsens, NK would take advantage to pressure US. 
Sec. of State Blinken said on December 14, 2021, that the US “seeks serious and sustained diplomacy with the DPRK.” The Biden Administration is willing to meet with North Korean representatives, “anytime, anywhere, without preconditions.” But the Biden admin is not likely to be involved in the pageantry of the Trump summit that may have flattered KJU but that other than didn't accomplish much more than a distraction.
There is an increasing probability on their reaching this goal. There appears to be motivation to proceed.

Seven missile tests in the last month strongly signal Kim is yet again looking for economic concessions. Indications seem to point toward a looming North Korean humanitarian crisis in the wake of western economic sanctions, COVID-19, and closing its border with China. As a result, DPRK may continue to escalate until diplomatic preconditions that are in its favor are accepted. The latest IRBM test is a further indication of this approach. With that said, if North Korea warms to talks then continued escalation towards the 9000-11000km range may not occur.  Another key event to keep an eye on is the presidential election in South Korea. Depending on which party takes office could change the calculus for North Korea.  https://apnews.com/article/north-korea-tests-longest-range-missile-since-biden-started-37f273d0602f91d392d32b6c0d4002ee
They really want to, but can they do it?
https://www.wsj.com/articles/north-korea-launches-suspected-ballistic-missile-off-its-east-coast-south-korea-says-11643502959 And, given instability with Russia, this may increase the odds.

Increasing chances until rhetoric from NK and  frequency of tests/launches decreases. This is clearly one of those questions where the outcome can change on a dime. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/1/30/pyongyang-continues-january-launch-spree-as-new-rockets-spotted “North Korea on Friday confirmed it had tested two long-range cruise missiles, and said earlier this month it considered resuming “all temporarily suspended activities”, hinting that it might lift a self-imposed moratorium on testing nuclear bombs and intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs).“

Sooner or later The Pyongyang Kid will decide he's not getting enough attention, which he equates with respect, from the other children.   Getting one of these up in the air is or will soon be within his capabilities, and firing it would scare the other children less than a nuke.  Might not make it this year, though.  (Full disclosure:  Li'l Kim does not confide in me.)

Keep my forecast 75%, YES.  FoxNews, CNN, HLN, and MSNBC are all reporting North Korea has tested 6 missiles in the last few months, shooting two missiles simultaneously in one test.  It is likely the North will continue to hone its capability. On the other hand, China still seeks recovery from its "Millenium of Humiliation."  Since China backs North Korea's economy and military endeavors, it often speaks up if it does not approve.  China may assess the tests as too frequent and try to encourage them to stop.

Raising forecast slightly. CNN, 1 hour ago: "North Korea has fired what are presumed to be two short-range ballistic missiles into waters off the east coast of the Korean Peninsula — a move believed to be its sixth missile test this month, the South Korean military said." https://twitter.com/CNN/status/1486520801046282240
Updating upon further launches into the Sea of Japan.
(no change) AV Week reports the last three tests were of a MARV (MAneuverable Re-entry Vehicle), not a more difficult HGV.

Moved slightly towards "yes" based on recent tactical launches, but not much.  Found this historical overview helpful, but I'm not seeing a specific pattern (yet). https://missilethreat.csis.org/north-korea-missile-launches-1984-present/

With everything else going on in the world and North Korea's need for attention, the possibility of this seems increasingly likely, but the real question remains, do they really have the technology and ability to launch an ICBM 10,000km?

Thanks to key information found by @alh: https://twitter.com/GalloVOA/status/1483921671778185225
It appears N Korea has 2 important birthdays to celebrate this year: the 110th birth anniversary of Kim Il Sung and the 80th birth anniversary of Kim Jong Il - in addition to the 90th anniversary of the founding of the Korean People's Army. There's going to be a very big celebration. And with such celebrations come displays of military might. "The Politcal Bureau of the Party Central Committee... came to a conclusion that it must go over to practical actions to consolidate more reliably and more precisely our physical strength for defending the dignity of our state and its national rights and interests. The meeting reconfirmed the tasks of defence policy to strengthen and develop without delay more powerful physical means to definitely overpower the daily intensifying hostile moves of the United States. It instructed the field concerned... to rapidly examine the issue on resuming all actions which had been temporarily suspended. The decision adopted at the meeting is a timely and just measure to reliably guarantee the existence of our state and its sovereignty...." "our physical strength": Nuclear weapons.
"more reliably": Let's have fewer "accidents," please.
"more precisely": Let's continue miniaturizing warheads to fit in smaller nose cones, to allow optimizing nose cone design for better missile targeting. Probably also a reference to developing tactical nuclear weapons, which they are moving towards, too.
"more powerful physical means": Let's develop longer-range missiles and missiles that can carry larger payloads.
"to rapidly examine the issue on resuming all actions which had been temporarily suspended": Let's resume testing of nuclear weapons and long-range missiles. I think it's pretty clear we can expect an ICBM to be tested in this big anniversary year. And when there is an accident, it's usually after a missile has left the ground. Later note: Day of the Sun = Kim Il Sung's birthday is April 15. Day of the Shining Star = Kim Jong Il's birthday is February 16. If I had to pick a month in which an ICBM would be tested, I'd pick April. I don't have a lot of confidence in that, but it does seem very likely to me that testing will resume this year in honor of the major birth anniversary and army foundation celebrations.
Key issue is development. They certainly have the will to do it.

Failures for NK are not a problem.  They are learning tools to get better. Unlike the US system where a failure causes a congressional inquiry, NK's program is designed to test, improve, test, improve.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/01/14/north-korea-missiles-kim/ They seem pretty trigger happen when it comes to 'testing'. According to the BBC, they have at least 2 IBCM missiles.
A lot has been going on with North Korea and rockets over the past couple of weeks.
Tech is difficult and expensive. Failure is embarrassing. So unlikely unless there is some very specific outcome to be achieved.

Trump rhetoric with North Korea ratcheted up its nuke program, accelerating its desire to prove their ICBMs can range the US.  Test conducted 2017 to present have not fully validated the capability.  Medium and short-range missiles have been successful, but sustained pressure on a warhead in the atmosphere during a 10,000km journey has not been proven.  Biden administration has been unsuccessful in reinvigorating talks, and the US keeps sanctions in place, so North Korea is likely working on a test sometime soon.  within the next year, perhaps? See articles and wiki https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_North_Korean_missile_tests; https://www.wsj.com/articles/north-koreas-missiles-and-nuclear-weapons-everything-you-need-to-know-11610712018#:~:text=North%20Korea's%20most%20recent%20test,reach%20anywhere%20in%20the%20U.S.&text=Missile%20experts%20estimate%20its%20range,than%2030%20minutes%20after%20launch; https://www.npr.org/2022/01/18/1073745848/north-korea-tests-more-missiles-but-experts-warn-against-taking-threats-at-face-

this article is interesting in the context - https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-54500550#:~:text=North%20Korea%20already%20has%20two%20tested%20ICBMs.%20The,the%20US%20mainland%20carrying%20a%20single%20nuclear%20warhead. - will they test this new missile out as it likely has a range that exceeds 10000 km

Given the loose definition in the question, “An ICBM will be deemed to have launched if there is credible reporting that the missile left the ground,” the probability is probably higher than I would initially think. The DPRK may sable rattle before US mid-terms.

The real question is, does North Korea has the ability to launch an ICBM 10,000km?  The question is not just about technological ability, but also economic, social welfare, diplomatic (as limited as it might be) abilities to launch.  There has been a will to further their ICBM capabilities in the past, but does it still persist?
They will continue to develop plans and tests. They are also going to receive greater cover by other adversarial countries like Russia and China etc.

Since North Korea first tested an ICBM in 2017, there have been 5 years and 2017 is the only one in which they tested an ICBM, giving a base rate of 20%. But technology advances each year and it seems they are off to a fast start with testing so far in 2022 according to the database linked by @Luukvv7

Fermitize problem:
1. Does North-Korea have an ICBM rocket with an estimated range of at least 10.000 km?
2. Will it test it between now (16th of January) and 1st of January 2023?
3. Will the test succeed?  1. North Korea already performed tests in 2017 with an ICBM rocket that could reach > 10.000 km. Also they presented a rocket in October 2020 which was supposedly an ICBM, even though there is always the questions whether it is real or 'fake'. I'll put this probability on 70%.  2. Tests in 2022: 2, tests in 2021: 6, tests in 2020: 1, tests in 2019: 10, tests in 2018: 0, tests in 2017: 15, tests in 2016: 5, tests in 2015: 1
39 in 6 years: 6.5 on average per year since 2015. This year already two, so 4.5 remaining.  (link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_North_Korean_missile_tests) Long range missiles have not been tested since 2017 (link: https://missilethreat.csis.org/country/dprk/) Most recent tests in 2022 are done with the Hwasong-8, which is not supposed to reach >10.000 km. In 2017 there were 6 tests performed with the Hwasong-12 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hwasong-12) indicating that they mostly perform with similar rockets. Hard to say, put it on 40%.  3. Tests are successes most of time time (+- 75%), but assuming not all failed tests are seen let's say it's a 60% succes ratio. according to https://www.nti.org/analysis/articles/cns-north-korea-missile-test-database/.
4,5 options remaining so (1-0.6)^(4.5) = 1.6% change that it will fail. Or 98.4% change they will succeed.  They will and succeed: 0.7 * 0.4 * 0.984 = 28%
They will but not succeed: 0.7 * 0.4 * 0.016 0.5%
They won't, all others: 71.5%
Add last two up, since that won't succeed: So [28 72]

(no change) Good tutorial on different aspects related to hypersonics. I agree mostly "shrug worthy." https://www.npr.org/2022/01/15/1072385995/north-korea-is-testing-hypersonic-weapons-should-the-west-be-worried
Their priorities now seem to be hypersonic missiles, no need for long range testing for a while perhaps?
It is enough for them to attack South Korea and/or Japan. Nothing more is needed.

Yesterday, the DPRK launched two supposedly ballistic missiles from Pyonganpukto province towards the Sea of ​​Japan, Yonhap news agency reported.  Japan is protesting North Korea over the missile launch, Defense Minister Nobuo Kishi said.

Question specifies ICBM and minimum range of 10,000km
NK have been developing capability and famine doesn’t seem to reduce spending. 
There is a good chance of this, at least as a diversion from anything else going on in NK
@alh mentioned that the 90th birthday of the army is in April. That would be a choice occasion for displaying a new design and possibly doing a launch. Raising my forecast a little.

A qualifying missile launch clearly doesn’t happen very frequently. Best estimate is therefore “no”, but there is obviously high uncertainty on how this Question will resolve. https://www.nti.org/analysis/articles/cns-north-korea-missile-test-database/
Averaging my forecasts. It's totally reasonable testing is imminent, yet totally reasonable if testing is say 3 years away. The range is wide and thus I am not too sure.

So even if it blows up seconds after launch, it would count, I guess. 
DPRK has been trying to acquire materials used in long-range missiles: https://twitter.com/ArmsControlWonk/status/1482029904753577988
That would suggest that they're at least contemplating building ICBMs.
